title: Crime
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: — Naw, I shiteth thee not; you said something like: 'I do itto get the bad bastards out there. Ask any of the most vulnerablepeople in Muirhouse or Niddrie who they really fear and they'llall tell you that it's the bad bastards in their own midst.' So I saidsomething to the effect of: 'Fine, Raymond, but what about therich bad bastards?'

title: The Abbot

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: A common stratagem having been thus eludedin an extraordinary manner, the king's party resolved to assail Niddrie by open force; and todeter them from their purpose, the queen's lordsissued from Edinburgh, attacked Merchiston withcannon, pierced the wall with bullets, and sweptfrom the adjacent fields a considerable spoil ofcattle. But while the garrison were entering intosome treaty of surrender, a number of countrypeople, attracted by the noise of the firing, appearedso unexpectedly, and in such numbers as to startlethe besiegers, who, conceiving themselves on thepoint of being attacked by Morton's whole force,gave over their attack on the little fortalice, andwithdrew in such disorder that they were assailedby Morton with advantage, and put to flight, throwing away their weapons, and losing some prisoners.

title: Trainspotting
author: Welsh, Irvine
snippet: That wis bullshit. Beggar's brother, Joe, was stabbed in a fight in a pub at Niddrie years ago. The fight wis ay his ain makin, and he wisnae badly hurt.

title: Secretar. Founded on the story of the Casket Letters
author: Beatty, W.
snippet: In this fashion it came aboutthat we found ourselves once more in Scotland. We landed atDumbarton, from whilk place we went on with lord Flemingand the Frenchman to Niddrie, where I had my first view ofthe Secretar, who had come out from Embro to confer with theAmbassador. But, alack ! what a change was there in him.

title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: It was not till after she became a woman that she taught herself to read and write ; and then she read incessantly. She must have been about 60 before I ever saw her, which was chiefly, and often, at Niddrie. Her dress was always the same a man s hat when out of doors, and generally when within them, a cloth covering exactly like a man s great-coat, buttoned closely from the chin to the ground, worsted stockings, strong shoes with large brass clasps.

title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: After a long and unbroken course of domestic security and pleasure, death began, about 1815, to extinguish, and circumstances to scatter, the gay and amiable family of which I was virtually a member ; and I have since seldom revisited the generally silent walls. But the days of Niddrie are among the last I can forget.

title: Memorials of his time,
author: Cockburn, Henry Cockburn
snippet: For many years almost all my Saturdays, Sun days, and holidays, were passed at Niddrie. I sighed over every holiday as lost, that was not.

title: Reheated Cabbage

title: Memorials of his time,
